What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a lot of insight into The Arabian Nights and its many adaptations. I had never learned about any text like it before, and I really enjoyed it!

I learned so much about the Arabian Nights as a text as well as a long-lasting cultural phenomenon which has become so ubiquitous in American life. As someone who had never studied a lot of literature in translation before (especially not from Arabic), I learned how to approach stories in translation and analyze them for certain nuances that I would never have been able to find otherwise.
A broad exploration of the Arabian Nights across different translations and adaptations.

I learned so much from this course. I loved all the different mediums we looked at the 1001 Nights through, and all the different modes of thinking we used. I found it very valuable to focus on one text in many different iterations through the semester.
I learned a lot of interesting new facts about the Arabian Nights!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is very interesting, the discussions are engaging, and the group collaboration projects were really nice.

Strengths: There were so many opportunities for creative engagement with the Arabian Nights and collaboration with others in the class. We also got a fair amount of history and background, which was incredibly helpful when analyzing the stories for their social/historical significance. I really loved when we got to meet in groups before class and come up with a mini presentation about a specific topic-- it made it feel more like a real, in person class even in the virtual setting.

Weaknesses: The only weakness I can think of is that sometimes, the comments on the papers were a bit vague and didn't seem to leave a lot of room for improvement. For example, our papers were only 2-3 pages, but most of the comments were "elaborate on this" or "explain more," which were hard to do with zero space and very open-ended prompts. These were some of the more tricky papers I've had to write for the English major, specifically due to this space requirement.

Strengths the variation in the readings, and the assignments!
Weaknesses There were some days when discussions turned into lectures, and vice-versa... I wish it was a little clearer when we were encouraged to chime in, or sit back and take notes.

The material in this course was absolutely amazing. I mean, it's the Arabian Nights, you really can't go wrong. I'm just sad we couldn't watch the movies together as we would have done in-person, but I really enjoyed the class and the people in it.

This course is great! Main strengths are Prof Creswell and our TA Maru. They were both wonderful and engaging and fun. I also liked the balance of professor lecture with student presentations, groups, and projects. I felt like this was the one class this semester that I actually made friends in, because the format of the class facilitated that so well. I really enjoyed being a part of this class.

Strengths: Prof. Creswell and Maru, literary translations of Nights tales, focus on Arabic literary and cultural conventions, Nights stories are engaging and entertaining
Weaknesses: Stories can feel repetitive

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Everything was successful on Zoom.

I loved our small-group virtual meetings where we made presentations to give in class! This made it feel more like a normal course, even though it was virtual. I also liked when we went into breakout rooms.
I was surprised at how group assignments still worked, even virtually. This was a fun way to engage with classmates outside the virtual classroom.
Prof Creswell did a great job handling this class during Covid. He kept it interesting and made good use of the different virtual opportunities available to us.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I really liked the content of this course and its focus on one text (and then its adaptations). It was nice to spend so long going deeply into one subject.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially if you're not afraid to step outside your comfort zone and think in a new way about literature in translation! I was struggling a bit with the work load (papers/projects every other week with quite a few discussion posts/group meetings), but I ended up really loving it towards the end of the class.
Absolutely! Really fun content, well-presented throughout the course.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student! The readings are amazing, and the discussions on its modern interpretations were so much fun.
Yes!! This class was fun, engaging, and interesting. I made friends, found a great new professor, and learned a ton about a subject I previously knew nothing about.
The best medieval requirement-fulfilling Comp. Lit. class by far. Would recommend to majors and non-majors looking for an entertaining class that's pretty relaxed but still engaging
Yes, it is fun.
